blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
One of the most exotic places in Dalmatia I was preparing to visit for years is the Blaca Desert on the island of Brač. It was only last winter that I finally made this wish of my come true. The unapproachable monastery, hidden in the Brač gorges, leaves you breathless at the moment you lay eyes on the first assembly of the monastery houses, after a 30-minute walk from the nearest parking lot. This is an incredible monument to human work, resilience and effort in the crags of Brač.

The monastery is hiding a truly beautiful story and it is a great pity that it has been deserted for years. It was built when the Glagoites from Poljica arrived on the island of Brač while running away from the Turks, in 16th century. In 1552 they founded a cooperative of the monks and started farming the land which was given to them, while in 1570 they received the rector’s permit to build a monastery and a church. Thus the first buildings of the monastery assembly came to life.

The monastery reached its economic upswing at the beginning of 19th century, with the founding of the shipping association, along with the Bol captains of the Nikolorić family. It is then that Blaca became a rich and large estate, inherited by priests, relatives of the Desert’s manager. The last manager of the Blaca Desert, from the year 1862 till the end, were the Miličevićs of the Poljice family from Zvečanj, don Nikola Miličević and his nephew don Nikola Miličević jr.

The Dessert reached its cultural and economic peak at the time of don Nikola Miličević sr., who established a print house in the Dessert, obtaining from Milan a small printing machine with many boxes full of different letters. He gave a gift to his successor – a piano bought in Vienna, and there is an interesting anecdote regarding that. The piano was shipped to a 3 km distanced Pop’s harbor and 12 villagers carried it on their shoulders, drinking along the way as much as 56 liters of sacred wine. Don Niko sr. died in 1923, leaving an indelible trace in the history of the monastery. He demonstrated an exquisite skill in managing the assets and was truly innovative, which could best be seen in the production of honey. The honey was exported to Trieste and Vienna, and inside the monastery it was used as food sweetener and a natural remedy. In one year the Dessert could produce as much as 10 tons of honey, which was more than the entire Dalmatia altogether. Fascinating, right? It does not come as a surprise to hear that don Niko built in 1905 a unique apiary with 266 bee hives, fine minutes away from the monastery. Unfortunately, it is today completely ruined and destroyed… Don Niko died in 1923 and his nephew, don Niko jr., took over the monastery.

Don Niko jr. studied theology in Vienna, where he became interested also in astronomy, because he was living with the university observatory director prof. Edmund Weiss. After prof. Weiss died, don Niko took over his entire astronomy library and transferred it to his Blato observatory. There he used to observe the sky and write many discussions for foreign magazines, publishing in 1912 the first astronomic magazine in Croatia, “A young stargazer”. In 1926 he brought a Brenner telescope to the monastery. It had been at the moment the largest one in the Balkans and it cost the entire annual budget of the monastery – a million dollars. Because of his contribution, the International Astronomical Union named two asteroids, discovered from Višnjan observatory, Miličević and Brač, in the memory of the astronomer and his little observatory.

In 1963, after don Niko jr.’s death, the monastery is closed down, because his nephew showed no interest in becoming a priest, and became the property of Brač municipality. Today it is the property of Republic of Croatia.

This universally beautiful corner of the universe definitely deserves to be visited. Let us all hope that one day it will be revived and again inhabited.

Igor Goleš
blog_graphql.tekstBlogaHr:
Jedno od najegzotičnijih mjesta u Dalmaciji koje sam se godinama spremao posjetiti je Pustinja Blaca na otoku Braču. I tek prošlu zimu napokon sam si tu želju   i ostvario.  Samostan skriven u bračkim klisurama ostavlja bez daha kada vam se nakon 30 minutne šetnje ukaže prvi sklop samostanskih kuća. Nevjerovatan je to spomenik ljudskom radu i trudu u vrletima otoka Brača.

Samostan nudi zaista prekrasnu priču i velika je šteta što je već desetljećima napušten.  Nastao je kada su poljički glagoljaši  bježeći pred turcima dospjeli na otok Brač u 16. st.  Brački knez im je dao dozvolu za naseliti se pod spiljom Ljubitovicom . 1552 osnivaju redovničku zadrugu i počinju obrađivati zemlju koja im je poklonjena, a 1570. od  kneza dobivaju dozvolu za izgradnju samostana i crkve, te tako nastaju prve građevine samostanskog sklopa.

Samostan  gospodarski uzlet doživljava početkom 19. st. zahvaljujući osnutku brodarskog društva s bolskim kapetanima iz obitelji Nikolorić. Blaca su tada postala bogati veleposjed koji su nasljeđivali svećenici, rođaci upravitelja Pustinje. Zadnji upravitelji Pustinje Blaca , od 1862. vode  bili su Miličevići iz poljičke obitelji  iz Zvečanja, don Nikola Milićević stariji i njegov nećak don Nikola Milićević mlađi.

Kulturni zenit dostigla je u vrijeme don Nikole Milićevića starijeg , koji je u njoj oformio tiskaru, nabavivši iz Milana mali tiskarski stroj sa mnogo sanduka raznih slova. Svom nasljedniku poklonio je  klavir kupljen u Beču  uz kojeg je vezana zanimljiva anegdota. Klavir je brodom dopremljen u 3km udaljenu Popovu luku i na ramenima ga je do samostana prenašalo čak 12 težaka koji su pritom popili čak 56 litara mladog misnog vina. Dok Niko stariji umro je 1923, ostavivši neizbrisiv trag u povijesti samostana, pokazavši iznimno umijeće upravljanja imovinom i inovativnosti koja se najbolje očitala kod proizvodnje meda, koji je  izvozio u Trst i Beč, a unutar samostana se koristio za zaslađivanje hrane i prirodni lijek.  U godini dana  Pustinja je znala proizvesti i do 10 tona meda što je bio veći prinos nego u cijeloj Dalmaciji. Fascinantno zar ne ?

Stoga i ne čudi da je don Niko 1905.  izgradio na 5 minuta hoda od samostana i prekrasan kameni pčelinjak s 266 košnica, a koji je nažalost danas totalno derutan i porušen….

Dok Niko mlađi studirao je teologiju u Beču, gdje se zainteresirao za astronomiju jer je stanovao kod direktora sveučilišne zvjezdarnice prof. Edmunda Weissa i po njegovoj smrti je preuzeo njegovu cijelu astronomsku biblioteku koju je potom prenio u svoj blatački opservatorij. Odatle je motrio nebo i pisao mnogobrojne rasprave u inozemnim časopisima, a  1912. je izdao prvi astronomski časopis na tlu Hrvatske ˝Mladi zvjezdar ˝.  1926. u samostan je dopremio Brennerov teleskop, tada najveći na Balkanu za čiju je nabavku izdvojen godišnji proračun samostana od milijun dolara. Zbog njegovih doprinosa dva su asteroida, otkrivena sa zvjezdarnice Višnjan, odlukom Međunarodne astronomske unije dobila naziv Milićević i Brač na spomen astronoma i njegove male zvjezdarnice.

  1. nakon smrti don Nike mlađeg samostan se gasi jer njegov nećak nije pokazao interes za školovanjem za svećenika, te prelazi u vlasništvo općine Brač, a danas je vlasništvo RH.

Ovo komadić svemira univerzalne ljepote svakako zaslužuje da ga se posjeti, i s najvećim poštovanjem njegovim graditeljima to i preporučujem.

 

Igor Goleš
